items.content:
Quantitative calculations and qualitative interpretations are fundamental to fully grasp the concepts of chemistry. Quantitative values must include a number and a unit. Two common units of measurement are the conventional (English) system and the metric system. The conventional set of units includes inches, feet, miles, gallons, and pounds. These units, although common in the United Kingdom and the United States, are not used in science or by most of the world. The metric system's base-10 units are easier to use and essential for scientific calculations.

Prefixes are used in both systems, but they are more commonly used in the metric system because the metric system is base-10.

http://www.npl.co.uk/reference/measurement-units/si-prefixes/

In chemistry, the SI prefixes k (kilo), m (milli), µ (micro), and n (nano) are often used, eg 10 µg means 10*10-6 g

The modern metric system uses SI (Systè me Internationale d'Unité s) units that have seven base units (see Table). All other units are derived from these base units such as area (m2), volume (m3 or 1,000 liters), speed (m/s), force (kg m/s2 or newton, N), and energy (kg m2/s2 or joule, Nm).

Volume

The unit of content (symbol V) is an example of a derived unit. The SI unit is cubic meter (m3). In chemistry, the unit for volume used is mostly liter (symbol L).

1 L = 1 dm3 = 0,001 m3 = 10-3 m3

or

1 m3 = 1000 dm3 = 1000 L

Bron: McMurray & Fay, Chemistry

In a lab, even a liter is usually a lot.

Therefore, smaller volumes are used:

1 cm3 = 0,001 dm3 = 10-3 dm3 = 1 mL = 0,001 L,

or even:

1 µL = 10-3 mL =10-6 L.

Uncertainty expresses the doubt associated with the accuracy of any single measurement. Accuracy establishes
how close in agreement a measurement is with the accepted value. The precision of a measurement is
the degree to which successive measurements agree with each other (the average deviation is minimized).
Error is the difference between a value obtained experimentally and the standard value accepted by the scientific
community. Consider the bull's-eye target patterns
Scientific notation:

The number of significant figures in any physical quantity or measurement is the number of digits
known precisely to be accurate. The last digit to the right is inaccurate. The rules for counting significant figures are as follows:

  1. All nonzero digits are significant.
  2. Zeros between nonzero digits are significant figures.
  3. Zeros that locate the decimal place (placeholder) on the left are nonsignificant.
  4. Trailing zeros to the right of the decimal point are significant if a decimal point is present.

Example

The value 5200 has at least 2 significant figures, and maximal 4 significant figure.

The scientific notiation with 2 significant figures would be 5.2*103.

When the 5200 would have 4 significant figures, the scientific notation would be 5.200 *103.


The value 5200.0 has 5 significant figures. Scientific notation: 5.2000 *103.

Example Significant figures Rule
5.20 3 1,4
0.2000 4 1,4
0.0020 2 1,3,4
0.0105 3 1,2,4
52000.0 6 1,4

questions.label: Identify the number of signiﬁcant ﬁgures in the following numbers.
Identify the number of signiﬁcant ﬁgures in the following numbers.

items.content:
Multiplication and division:

The answer will have the same number of signiﬁcant ﬁgures as the least precise number.

56.2 * 0.25 = 14.05 = 14 (0.25 is limiting with two signiﬁcant ﬁgures)

= 1.0878 = 1.09 (12.3 is limiting with three signiﬁcant ﬁgures)

Addition and subtraction: The answer will have the same number of decimal places as the least precise number.

12.01 + 1.008 = 13.018 = 13.02 (12.01 is limiting with two decimal places)

65.2 - 12.95 = 52.25 = 52.3 (65.2 is limiting with one decimal place)

When more than one operation is involved in a calculation, note the number of signiﬁcant ﬁgures in each operation, but round only the ﬁnal answer.

27.43 + 3.32 * 25.61 = 27.43 + 85.0252 = 112.4552 = 113 (Three signiﬁcant ﬁgures)

heading.content: Chemical Composition: Atoms, Molecules, and Ions

items.content:
In 1808, John Dalton published A New System of Chemical Philosophy, which proposed his hypotheses about the nature of matter. Dalton's atomic theory explained that

  • all elements are made of tiny, indivisible particles called atoms (from the Greek atomos, meaning indivisible).
  • atoms of one element are identical in size, mass, and chemical properties.
  • atoms of different elements have different masses and chemical properties.
  • compounds are made up of atoms of different elements in a ratio that is an integer (i.e., whole number) or a simple fraction.
  • atoms cannot be created or destroyed. They can be combined or rearranged in a chemical reaction.

Subsequent experiments, notably those of J.J. Thomson (discoverer of the electron), E. Rutherford (who estab- lished that the atom was made of a dense, central core called a nucleus, positively charged by protons, and separated from moving electrons by empty space), and others such as A. Becquerel and Marie Curie (on the spontaneous disintegration of some nucleus with the emission of particles and radiation), were necessary, however, to complete the understanding of atoms.

The atomic weight (or mass) of an element is given by the weighted average of the isotopes' masses. Isotopes are atoms of an element that have different masses.

Dalton's atomic theory allowed scientists to understand and formulate three laws based on Dalton's hypothesis:

  1. Law of conservation of mass: The law of conservation of mass is derived from Dalton's ﬁfth hypothesis and states that mass cannot be cre- ated or destroyed. If the mass of the combined reactants is 20 grams, then the mass of the com- bined products must be 20 grams.
  2. Law of deﬁnite proportions: The law of deﬁnite proportions is derived from Dalton's fourth hypothesis and states that different samples of the same compound always contain the same propor- tion by the mass of each element. Water (H2O) always has a ratio of 2 grams of hydrogen to 16 grams of oxygen regardless of the sample size.
  3. Law of multiple proportions: The law of multi- ple proportions is also derived from Dalton's fourth hypothesis and states that if two elements combine to form multiple compounds, the ratio of the mass of one element combined with the 1 gram of the other element can always be reduced to a whole number. Hydrogen can combine with oxygen in two ways: water (H2O) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). The ratio of oxygen is 1:2.

Elements are deﬁned by their atomic number. An element's atomic number is the number of protons in the atom and is sometimes written as a subscript of the elemental symbol (i.e., 11Na). Because the atomic number deﬁnes the elemental symbol (sodium always has 11 protons and carbon always has 6 protons), the atomic number is frequently omitted.

Also important is the mass number of an element. The mass number is the sum of protons and neutrons (in the nucleus) of the atom and is written as a superscript of the element's symbol (23Na).

Isotopes are atoms of the same element with the same number of protons (same atomic number) but different number mass numbers (due to a different number of neutrons). Isotopes have identical chemical properties (the same reactivity) but different physical properties (i.e., some are radioactive, while others are stable). Consider the three isotopes of hydrogen in Table 2.1

items.content: As noted earlier, the periodic table is organized in octaves (Groups 1,2,13,14,15,16,17 and 18). The octet rule states that atoms form ions and are bond by surrounding themselves with eight (octet) outer electrons. They tend to acquire the stability of their closest noble gases (group 18) in the periodic table either by losing (metals), or gaining (non- metals), electrons.

A negative charged ion formed when an atom gains one or more electrons. The non-metal atoms tends to become negatively charged. Their names are derived from the elemental name with an -ide sufﬁx.

For example, when chlorine (Cl) (a non-metal) gains an electron, a chloride ion (Cl-) is formed. Because chlorine is in group 17, it only needs to gain one electron to achieve the octet structure of the noble gas argon (Ar). By gaining one electron it has the same electron structure as the noble gas argon and becomes very stable. In fact, all halogens (the elements in group 17) gain 1 electron when they become an ion.

An oxygen atom (O) acquires two electrons to form an oxide ion (O2-) that has the same stable electron conﬁguration as the noble gas neon (Ne).

A positively charged ion is formed when an atom loses one or more electrons. Most positive ions are metallic and have the same name as the metallic element. For example, when lithium (Li) loses an electron, a lithium ion (Li+) is formed. Lithium is in group 1 and needs to lose one electron to acquire the noble gas electron structure of helium (He), the closest noble gas. All elements in group 1 behave this way. The elements in group 1 loose 1 electron.

The elements in group 2 loose 2 electrons to acquire the noble gas electron structure. For example, when magnesium (Mg) looses electrons, a magnesium ion is formed: Mg2+

items.content:
Atoms and molecules are too small to count and would require extremely large numbers. Chemists must have an understanding and a unit of measurement to answer "How much is there?"

The mole (6.022 * 1023) is a unit of measurement that describes matter, just as a gross (a group of 144 things, like two gross of apples, meaning 288 apples) or a dozen (a group of 12 things, like two dozen of apples meaning 24 apples) describes a quantity of consumer products. The mole describes a group of 6.022 * 1023 things.

In chemistry it is convenient to use a unit called a mol.

If a chemist understands the behavior of 1 particle, then the same applies to a mol of particles.

  • A mole of a particular substance is equal to the number of atoms in exactly 12 g of the carbon-12 isotope.
  • Experiments established that number to be 6.022142 * 1023 particles. This number is known as the Avogadro constant, NA.
  • The molar mass of a substance is the mass, in grams, of one mol of a substance.

The atomic mass of an element can be found in the periodic table. Carbon has an atomic weight 12.01u, and iron has an atomic weight of 55.85u. The molar mass of a molecule is calculated by adding all the atomic molar masses. You can use the periodic table in your book (p236) to find the atomic weight of the elements, or use this webpage: webelements

The atomic mass of hydrogen is 1.008 u, the mass of an atom is given in atomic mass units, symbol u.

Calculating the molar mass is basically using the atomic mass but changing the unit in g/mol.

Remember that 1 mol of hydrogen contains the same amount of atoms as 1 mol of carbon atoms.

We defined a mol using the element carbon:

If 1 atom of carbon has a mass of 12u, and a mole of carbon atoms has a mass of 12g,

The same applies to the mass hydrogen:
if 1 atom of hydrogen has a mass of 1u (meaning 1/12 th of the mass of a carbon atom),
then a mole of hydrogen has a mass of 1g (also 1/12 th of the mass of a mole of carbon atoms)

To calculate the mass of a mole of a compound you can simply find the individual atomic masses, add them up, find the total weight of the molecule and use as a unit g/mol.

Example:

Mr, H2O = mass of 2 hydrogen atoms + mass of 1 oxygen atom = 2*1.008+15.99 = 18.02g/mol

Symbol Mr, relative molecular mass; sometimes Mw is used as a symbol for molecular weight, however this is an older term

items.caption: What is molar mass? Counting atoms!

items.content:
Example

What is the molar mass of carbon dioxide?

Solution

Carbon dioxide is CO2, which contains 1 atom of carbon and 2 atoms of oxygen

Molar mass of CO2 = 12.01 + 2(16.00) = 44.01 g/mol

header.title: Calculate the molar mass of the following chemicals

introduction.body: Calculate the molar mass of the following chemicals

items.content:
Example

How many moles are there in 62.5 grams of NaHCO3?

Solution

The molar mass of sodium bicarbonate is needed.
22.99 + 1.008 + 12.01 + 3(16.00) = 84.008 g/mol

62.5g / 84.008g/mol = 0.744 moles NaHCO3

prompt.body: number of moles of nitrogen trioxide in 67.8 g
number of grams in 2.5 moles of acetic acid

heading.content: Gases: Calculations using the molar volume

items.content: If you think of substances at micro scale (atomic or molecular level), the distance between particles depends on the state the substance is in. In the next figure this is illustrated.

items.altText: Figure 1: Particles of sodium in the solid, liquid, and gas phases are shown. The atoms of gaseous sodium are much farther apart, as in a sodium vapor street lamp.

items.content:
Gases Have Low Density

Gases have much lower densities than liquids and solids do. Because of the relatively large distances between gas particles, most of the volume occupied by a gas is empty space. As shown in Figure 1, particles in solids and liquids are almost in contact with each other, but gas particles are much farther apart. This distance between particles shows why a substance in the liquid or solid state always has a much greater density than the same substance in the gaseous state does. The low density of gases also means that gas particles travel relatively long distances before colliding with each other.

Gases Are Highly Compressible

Suppose you completely fill a syringe with liquid and try to push the plunger in when the opening is plugged. You cannot make the space the liquid takes up become smaller. It takes very great pressure to reduce the volume of a liquid or solid. However, if only gas is in the syringe, with a little effort you can move the plunger down and compress the gas. As shown in Figure 2, gas particles can be pushed closer together. The space occupied by the gas particles themselves is very small compared with the total volume of the gas. Therefore, applying a small pressure will move the gas particles closer together and will decrease the volume.

items.altText: Figure 2: The volume occupied by a gas can be reduced because gas molecules can move closer together.

items.content:
Volume-Molar Relationships

In 1811, the Italian scientist Amadeo Avogadro proposed the idea that equal volumes of all gases, under the same conditions, have the same number of particles. This idea is shown in the next figure, which shows equal numbers of molecules of the gases H2, O2, and CO2, each having the same volume. A result of this relationship is that molecular masses can be easily determined. Unfortunately, Avogadro's insight was not recognized right away, mainly because scientists at the time did not know the difference between atoms and molecules. Later, the Italian chemist Stanislao Cannizzaro used Avogadro's principle to determine the true formulas of several gaseous compounds.

items.altText: Figure 3: At the same temperature and pressure, balloons of equal volume contain equal numbers of molecules, regardless of which gas they contain.

items.content:
Since the number of molecules of a gas in a certain volume is independent of the substance we can easily calculate the number of moles of a substance using the molar volume.

The molar volume of a gas is the volume occupied by one mol at 298K and standard atmospheric pressure (p=p0). It is equal to 24.5 dm3 at 298K, p=p0, so 1 mol gas has a volume of 24.5 L.

In formula: Vm, 298K = 24.5 L/mol

How to do the calculations is illustrated in the next examples

Example 1

What is the volume of 2.0 mol of carbon dioxide at 298K, standard pressure?

Remember you do not need to work out the molar mass to do this calculation as it does not matter what gas it is.

Solution 1

2.0 moles of carbon dioxide = 2 x 24.5 L = 49 L

Example 2

What is the volume of 0.00563 moles of chlorine molecules at 298K, standard pressure?

Solution 2

Volume of 0.00563 moles of chlorine = 0.00563 x 24.5 L = 0.1379 L = 138 mL

Example 3

Calculate the number of moles of hydrogen molecules in 245 mL of the gas at 298K, standard pressure?

Solution 3

245 mL hydrogen gas = 0.245 L; 24.5 L/mol

0.245 / 24.5 = 0.0100 mol = 1.00 * 10-2 mol H2 gas

Example 4

Calculate the volume of 10.00 g of hydrogen gas, at 298K, standard pressure?

This is a two-stage calculation, first you need to calculate how many moles of hydrogen gas are present and then you need to convert this to a volume.

Solution 4

Molar mass H2: 2* 1.008 = 2.016 g/mol

Number of moles of hydrogen gas in 10.00 g: 10 /2.016=4.960 mol H2

Vm,298K = 24.5 L/mol; 4.960*24.5 = 122 L H2 gas

Example 5

Calculate the mass of 1.00 L of carbon dioxide, at 298K, standard pressure?

Again this is a two-stage calculation: first you need to calculate the number of moles of carbon dioxide and then convert this to a mass.

Solution 5

Number of moles of carbon dioxide gas in 1.00L:

Vm,298K = 24.5 L/mol; 1.00/24.5 = 4.08*10-2 mol CO2 gas

Molar mass CO2: 12.02 + 2* 16.00 = 44.02 g/mol

Mass of 4.08*10-2 mol CO2 gas: 4.08*10-2 mol * 44.02 g/mol = 1.80 g CO2 gas

items.content:
The number of atoms or the mass percent of its elements can describe a compound's composition.

The percent composition by mass can be calculated by comparing the mass of one mole of each element to the molar mass of the compound.

Example

What is the percent composition for each element of glucose, C6H12O6?

Solution

First, calculate the mass of each element in 1 mol glucose:

carbon = 6 mol * 12.01 g/mol = 72.06 g

hydrogen = 12 mol * 1.008 g/mol= 12.10 g

oxygen = 6 mol * 16.00 g/mol = 96 g

Next, calculate the molar mass (sum of the previous masses) of glucose:

72.06 + 12.10 + 96.00 = 180.16 g C6H12O6

Finally, compare the mass of each element to the molar mass (i.e., a percent is the part over the whole multiplied by 100):

mass % of carbon = 72.06 g / 180.16 g * 100 = 40.00 %

mass % of hydrogen = 12.10 g / 180.16 g * 100 = 6.716 %

mass % of oxygen = 96.00 g / 180.16 g * 100 = 53.29 %

Check: Add the calculated percents to be sure they add to 100 within rounding errors.

40.00% + 6.716% + 53.29% = 100%

header.title: Calculate the mass percent for each element in each of the following compounds

introduction.body: Calculate the mass percent for each element in each of the following compounds

prompt.body: iron (III) oxide (tip: iron (III) means it contains Fe3+)

items.content:
An empirical formula is the simplest whole-number ratio of atoms in a molecule.

Glucose (C6H12O6) has an empirical formula of CH2O.

For an unknown compound, the empirical formula can be calculated if the mass of each element is known or if the percent of each element is known.

Example 1

Determine the empirical formula of a compound that is 78.14% boron and 21.86% hydrogen.

Solution 1

Because the mass percent is given, assume 100 g: 78.14 g boron and 21.86 g hydrogen.

Calculate the number of moles of each element:

  • Molar mass of boron = 10.811 g/mol,
    78.14 g / 10.811 g/mol = 7.2278 mol boron
  • molar mass of hydrogen= 1.008 g/mol;
    21.86 g / 1.008 g/mol = 21.687 mol hydrogen

Conclusion: 7.2278 mol boron is bound to 21.687 mol hydrogen

simplest whole-number ratio:

7.2278 mol boron : 21.687 mol hydrogen;

7.2278/7.2278 mol boron : 21.687/7.2278 mol hydrogen;

1 mol boron : 3 mol hydrogen;

Conclusion: emperical formula is BH3

Example 2

Determine the empirical formula of a compound that has 8.288 g carbon, 1.855 g hydrogen, and 11.04 g oxygen in a sample.

Solution 2

Calculate the number of moles of each element:

  • Molar mass of carbon = 12.02 g/mol,
    8.288 g / 12.02 g/mol = 0.6895 mol carbon
  • molar mass of hydrogen= 1.008 g/mol;
    1.855 g / 1.008 g/mol = 1.840 mol hydrogen
  • molar mass of oxygen= 16.00 g/mol;
    11.04 g / 16.00 g/mol = 0.6900 mol oxygen

simplest whole-number ratio:

0.6895 mol carbon : 1.840 mol hydrogen : 0.6900 mol oxygen

Because the lowest whole-number ratio is required, divide all moles by the lowest. In this situation, all divisors should be 0.6895.

0.6895/0.6895 mol carbon : 1.840/0.6895 mol hydrogen : 0.6900/0.6895 mol oxygen

1 mol carbon : 2.669 mol hydrogen : 1 mol oxygen

Because the compound must contain whole numbers, CH2.669O is not a valid formula. A multiplier must be used to create a whole-number ratio. In this case, notice that 2.669 is 2; it can be multiplied by 3 to yield 8. The ratio must stay the same, and all elements must be multiplied (or divided in some problems) by the same value.

1 mol carbon : 2.669 mol hydrogen : 1 mol oxygen

1*3 mol carbon : 2.669*3 mol hydrogen : 1*3 mol oxygen

3 mol carbon : 8 mol hydrogen : 3 mol oxygen

Conclusion: emperical formula is C3H8O3

items.caption: Calculating Molecular Formula from Empirical Formula

items.content: A chemical change or chemical reaction can be described by writing a chemical equation. A chemical equation uses chemical symbols to show what happens during a chemical reaction.

Let's look at the electrolysis of water, a decomposition reaction. When water is subjected to an electric current, hydrogen gas and oxygen gas are formed. A chemical equation can be written to show this reaction:

2H2O → 2H2 + O2

The arrow (→) means yields. The reactants are a substance that undergoes a change in a chemical reaction (the left side of the arrow). The products are a substance that is formed as a result of a chemical reaction (the right side of the arrow). The chemical equation is like a mathematical equation where both sides must be equal. Recall that mass cannot be created or destroyed. Therefore, we must balance the equation.

What does it mean when we write a chemical formula or equation? Answering this question isn't as easy as it sounds because a chemical symbol can have different meanings under different circumstances. Chemists use the same symbols to represent chemistry on both a small-scale, microscopic level and a large-scale, macroscopic level, and they tend to slip back and forth between the two levels without realizing the confusion this can cause for newcomers to the field.

On the microscopic level, chemical symbols represent the behaviour of individual atoms and molecules. Atoms and molecules are much too small to be seen, but we can nevertheless describe their microscopic behaviour if we read the equation 2 H2 + O2 → 2 H2O to mean "Two molecules of hydrogen react with one molecule of oxygen to yield two molecules of water." It's this microscopic world that we deal with when trying to understand how reactions occur, and it's often helpful to visualize a molecule as a collection of spheres stuck together. In trying to understand how H2 reacts with O2, for example, you might picture H2 and O2 molecules as made of two spheres pressed together and a water molecule as made of three spheres.

On the macroscopic level, formulas and equations represent the large-scale behaviors of atoms and molecules that give rise to visible properties. In other words, the symbols H2, O2, and H2O represent not just single molecules but vast numbers of molecules that together have a set of measurable physical properties. A single isolated H2O molecule is neither solid nor liquid nor gas, but a huge collection of H2O molecules appears to us as a colorless liquid that freezes at 0 °C and boils at 100 °C. Clearly, it's this macroscopic behavior we deal with in the laboratory when we weigh specific amounts of reactants, place them in a flask, and observe visible changes.

In the same way, a single atom of copper is neither solid, liquid, nor gas, does not conduct electricity, and has no color on a microscopic level. On a macroscopic level, however, a large collection of copper atoms appears to us as a shiny, reddish-brown metal that can be drawn into electrical wires or made into coins.

CHEMICAL ARITHMETIC: STOICHIOMETRY

Imagine a laboratory experiment-perhaps the reaction of ethene, C2H4, with hydrogen chloride, HCl, to prepare chloroethane, C2H5Cl, a colorless, low-boiling liquid that doctors and athletic trainers use as a spray-on anesthetic for minor injuries. You might note that in writing this and other equations, the designations (g) for gas, (l) for liquid, (s) for solid, and (aq) for aqueous solutions are often appended to the symbols of reactants and products to show their physical state. We'll do this frequently from now on.

How much ethene and how much hydrogen chloride should you use for your experiment? According to the coefficients of the balanced equation, a numerical ratio of the two reactants is needed. But because you can't count the reactant molecules, you have to weigh them. That is, you must convert a number ratio of reactant molecules, as given by coefficients in the balanced equation, into a mass ratio to be sure you are using the right amounts.

In any balanced chemical equation, the coefficients tell the number of formula units, and thus the number of moles, of each substance in the reaction. You can then use molar masses as conversion factors to calculate reactant masses. If you saw the following balanced equation for the industrial synthesis of ammonia, for instance, you would know that 3 mol of H2 (3 mol * 2.018 g/mol = 6.054 g) is needed for reaction with 1 mol of N2 (28.0 g) to yield 2 mol of NH3 (2 mol * 17.03 g/mol = 34.06 g).

In referring to the chemical arithmetic needed for mole-mass conversions, we use the word stoichiometry (stoy-key-ahm-uh-tree; from the Greek stoicheion, "element, " and metron, "measure").

Let's look again at the reaction of ethene with HCl and assume that we have 15.0 g of ethene and need to know how many grams of HCl to use in the reaction.

C2H4(g) + HCl(g) → C2H5Cl(l)

According to the coefficients in the balanced equation, 1 molecule of HCl reacts with 1 molecule of ethene, so 1 mol of HCl is needed for reaction with each mole of ethene. To find out how many grams of HCl are needed to react with 15.0 g of ethene, we first have to find out how many moles of ethene are in 15.0 g. We do this gram-to-mole conversion by calculating the molar mass of ethene and using that value as a conversion factor:

Molar mass of C2H4 = 28.0 g/mol

Moles of C2H4 = 15.0 g ethene / 28.0 g/mol ethene = 0.536 mol ethene

Now that we know how many moles of ethene we have (0.536 mol), we also know from the balanced equation how many moles of HCl we need (ratio 1:1, so same amount in moles; 0.536 mol), and we have to do a mole-to-gram conversion to find the mass of HCl required. Once again, the conversion is done by calculating the molar mass of HCl and using that value as a conversion factor:
Molar mass of HCl = 36.5 g/mol

Grams of HCl = 0.536 mol HCl * 36.5 g/mol HCl = 19.6 g HCl

Thus, 19.6 g of HCl is needed to react with 15.0 g of ethene.

items.altText: Conversions between moles and grams for a chemical reaction.  The numbers of moles tell how many molecules of each reactant are needed, as given by the coefficients of the balanced equation; the numbers of grams tell what mass of each reactant is needed.

header.title: Finding the mass of one reactant, given the mass of another

questions.label: Finding the mass of one reactant, given the mass of another

prompt.body:
Hydrogen gas reacts with carbon monoxide to yield methanol (CH3OH). How many grams of methanol are formed when 15.6 g of hydrogen

Hint: start with the balanced reaction equation!

values.value:
balanced reaction equation:

2H2 + CO → CH3OH

So, 2 mol of H2 forms 1 mol of CH3OH

Molar mass of H2= 2*1.008 = 2.016 g/mol

We have 15.6/2.016 = 7.74 mol H2, so also 7.74/2=3.87 mol CH3OH can be formed

Molar mass of CH3OH= 12.02 + 4*1.008 + 16.00 = 32.04 g/mol

Thus 3.87 mol * 32.04 g/mol = 124 g CH3OH can be formed

content.body:
balanced reaction equation:

2H2 + CO → CH3OH

So, 2 mol of H2 forms 1 mol of CH3OH

Molar mass of H2= 2*1.008 = 2.016 g/mol

We have 15.6/2.016 = 7.74 mol H2, so also 7.74/2=3.87 mol CH3OH can be formed

Molar mass of CH3OH= 12.02 + 4*1.008 + 16.00 = 32.04 g/mol

Thus 3.87 mol * 32.04 g/mol = 124 g CH3OH can be formed

questions.label: Finding the mass of one reactant, given the mass of another

prompt.body:
How many moles of carbon dioxide are formed in the fermentation of 75 g of glucose? During fermentation, also ethanol is formed.

Start your answer giving the balanced reaction equation

values.value:
balanced reaction equation:

C6H12O6 → 2CO2 + 2C2H5OH

So, 1 mol of C6H12O6 forms 2 mol of CO2

Molar mass of C6H12O6 = 180.16 g/mol

We have 75/180.16 = 4.2 * 10-1 mol C6H12O6 ,
so also 4.2*10-1 * 2 = 8.3*10-1mol CO2 can be formed

Molar mass of CO2= 44.01 g/mol

Thus 8.3*10-1mol * 44.01 g/mol = 36.6 g CO2 can be formed

content.body:
balanced reaction equation:

C6H12O6 → 2CO2 + 2C2H5OH

So, 1 mol of C6H12O6 forms 2 mol of CO2

Molar mass of C6H12O6= 180.16 g/mol

We have 75/180.16 = 4.2 * 10-1 mol C6H12O6,
so also 4.2*10-1 * 2 = 8.3*10-1mol CO2 can be formed

Molar mass of CO2= 44.01 g/mol

Thus 8.3*10-1mol * 44.01 g/mol = 36.6 g CO2 can be formed

questions.label: Finding the mass of one reactant, given the mass of another

prompt.body:
The thermite reaction can be used to ignite solid-fuel rockets or bombs. The unbalanced equation is as follows:

Fe2O3 + Al → Fe + Al2O3

How much aluminum (in g) is needed to react with 10.0 g of Fe2O3?

items.content:
Whenever the ratios of reactant molecules used in an experiment are different from those given by the coefficients of the balanced equation, a surplus of one reactant is left over after the reaction is finished. Thus, the extent to which a chemical reaction takes place depends on the reactant that is present in limiting amount-the limiting reactant. The other reactant is said to be the excess reactant.

The situation with excess reactants and limiting reactants is analogous to what sometimes happens with people and chairs. If there are five people in a room but only three chairs, then only three people can sit while the other two stand because the number of people sitting is limited by the number of available chairs. In the same way, if 5 moles of water come in contact with 3 moles of ethylene oxide, only 3 moles of water can undergo a reaction while the other 2 moles of water are unchanged.

Example

Identify the limiting reactant and how much ammonia gas can be produced when 8.0 g of nitrogen gas reacts with 8.0 g of hydrogen gas by the use of the Haber process: 3H2 + N2 → 2NH3.

Solution

Identify the amount given and needed:

3H2 + N2 → 2NH3.

8.0 g + 8.0 g → ?

Use the molar masses and mole ratios (coefﬁcients) to set up the calculation:

8 g H2, Mr, H2 = 2.016 g/mol; hence 8/2.016= 4 mol H2

8 g N2, Mr, N2 = 28.02 g/mol; hence 8/28.02= 0.29 mol N2

4 mol H2 will react with 4/3=1.3 mol N2 producing 2.6 mol NH3

0.29 mol N2 will react with 0.29*3=0.87 mol H2 producing 0.58 mol NH3

Thus N2 is limited, the reaction will produce 0.58 mol NH3, weighing 9.9 g

prompt.body: Identify the limiting reactant and how much ammonia gas can be produced when 7.2 g of nitrogen gas react with 1.5 g of hydrogen gas by the use of the Haber process: 3H2 + N2 --> 2NH3.
Identify the limiting reactant and how much car-bon dioxide gas can be produced when 15.2 g of methane react with 18.5 g of oxygen gas to produce water and carbon dioxide.
Identify the limiting reactant and how much nitric acid (HNO3) can be produced when 60.0 g of nitrogen dioxide react with 18.5 g of water to produce nitric acid and nitrogen monoxide.

Identify the limiting reactant and how much aspirin (C9H8O4) can be produced when 52.3 g of salicylic acid (C8H6O3) react with 25.0 g of acetic acid (CH3CO2H):

The unbalanced reaction equation:

C8H6O3 + CH3CO2H → C9H8O4 + H2O.

values.value: Limiting reactant  salicylic acid; theoretical yield  62.8 g

content.body: Limiting reactant salicylic acid; theoretical yield 62.8 g

items.content:
In the stoichiometry examples worked out in the preceding section, we made the unstated assumption that all reactions "go to completion." That is, we assumed that all reactant molecules are converted to products. In fact, few reactions behave so nicely. More often, a large majority of molecules react as expected, but other processes, or side reactions, also occur. Thus, the amount of product actually formed, called the yield of the reaction, is usually less than the amount predicted by calculations. The amount of product actually formed in a reaction divided by the amount theoretically possible and multiplied by 100% is the reaction's percent yield.
For example, if a given reaction could provide 6.9 g of a product according to its stoichiometry, but actually provides only 4.7 g, then its percent yield is 4.7/6.9 * 100% = 68%

Example

Methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE, C5H12O), a gasoline additive now being phased out in many places because of health concerns, can be made by reaction of 2-methylpropene (C4H8) with methanol (CH3OH). What is the percent yield of the reaction if 32.8 g of methyl tertbutyl ether is obtained from reaction of 26.3 g of isobutylene with sufficient methanol?

Strategy

First we write down the balanced reaction equation:

C4H8 + CH3OH → C5H12O

We conclude that 1 mole of C4H8 produces 1 mol C5H12O. We need to calculate the amount of C5H12O that could be produced theoretically from 26.3 g of 2-methylpropene and compare that theoretical amount to the actual amount (32.8 g).

As always, stoichiometry problems begin by

  • calculating the molar masses of reactants and products
  • coefficients of the balanced equation then tell mole ratios, and
  • molar masses act as conversion factors between moles and masses.

Solution

Molar mass of C4H8 = 56.0 g/mol

Molar mass of C5H12O = 88.0 g/mol

To calculate the amount of C5H12O that could theoretically be produced from 26.3 g of C4H8, we first have to find the number of moles of reactant, using molar mass as the conversion factor:

26.3/ 56.0 = 0.470 mol C4H8

According to the balanced equation, 1 mol of product is produced per mol of reactant, so we know that 0.470 mol of C4H8 can theoretically yield the same amount in moles of C5H12O, so 0.470 mol of C5H12O. Finding the mass of this C5H12O requires a mole-to-mass conversion:

0.470 mol C4H8 * 88.0 g/mol C5H12O = 41.4 g C5H12O

Dividing the actual amount by the theoretical amount and multiplying by 100% gives the percent yield:

32.8 g C5H12O/ 41.4 g C5H12O * 100% = 79.2%

questions.label: Calculate the percent yield

prompt.body: When 7.2 g of nitrogen gas react with 1.5 g of hydrogen gas by the use of the Haber process, 6.3 g of ammonia were produced. What was the percent yield? (see previous question)
When 15.2 g of methane react with 18.5 g of oxygen gas water and 12.4 g carbon dioxide was produced. Calculate the percent yield.
51 g nitric acid can be produced when 60.0 g of nitrogen dioxide react with 18.5 g of water to produce nitric acid and nitrogen monoxide. Calculate the percent yield.

31.0 g of aspirin (C9H8O4) were produced when 52.3 g of salicylic acid (C8H6O3) react with 25.0 g of acetic acid (CH3CO2H):

The unbalanced reaction equation:

C8H6O3 + CH3CO2H → C9H8O4 + H2O.

Calculate the percent yield

heading.content: Calculations of products/reactants based on equations

items.content:
Now you should know everything you need to know to do chemical calculations in tV3. If you still have problems, check out the films that were included with the text, or ask your teacher to give you a hand.

We end this lesson series with a final set of questions! At the end you can make a screenshot to proof that you have done all the tasks, hand it in via magister.

prompt.body:
What mass of bariumsulfate would be produced from 10 g of bariumchloride in the following reaction?

BaCl2 + H2SO4 → BaSO4 + 2HCl
What mass of potassiumchloride (KCl) would be produced from 20 g of potassium Carbonate (K2CO3)?
What mass of iron(III) oxide (Fe2O3) would need to be reduced to produce 100 tonnes of iron in a blast furnace?

What mass of silver nitrate (AgNO3) as a solution in water would need to be added to 5.0 g of sodium chloride (NaCl) to ensure complete precipitation of the chloride?

AgNO3(aq) + NaCl(aq) → AgCl(s) + NaNO3(aq)

A solution of copper sulfate reacts with sodium hydroxide solution to produce a precipitate of copper hydroxide according to the following equation:

CuSO4(aq) + 2NaOH(aq) → Cu(OH)2(s) + Na2SO4(aq)

What mass of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) would be needed to convert 15.96 g of coppersulfate to copperhydroxide and what mass of copperhydroxide would be produced?

What volume of ammonia gas would be needed to produce 40.0 g of ammonium nitrate in the following reaction (298K, p=p0)?

NH3(g) + HNO3(aq) → NH4NO3(aq)
In the reaction between calcium carbonate (CaCO3) and nitric acid (HNO3) what mass of calcium nitrate (Ca(NO3)2) and what volume of carbondioxide would be produced from 33.3 g of calcium carbonate?

Diethyl ether (C4H10O), the "ether" used medically as an anesthetic, is prepared commercially by treatment of ethyl alcohol (C2H6O) with an acid. How many grams of diethyl ether would you obtain from 40.0 g of ethyl alcohol if the percent yield of the reaction is 87%?

Next to C4H10O also another compound is formed, with only C2H6O as reactant.

Strategy:

Treat this as a typical stoichiometry problem to find the amount of diethyl ether that can theoretically be formed from 40.0 g of ethyl alcohol, and then multiply the answer by 87% to find the amount actually formed.

values.value:
0.435 mol diethyl ether can be formed maximal, corresponding with 32.2 g diethyl ether
32.2 g diethyl ether * 0.87 = 28 g diethyl ether

content.body:
0.435 mol diethyl ether can be formed maximal, corresponding with 32.2 g diethyl ether
32.2 g diethyl ether * 0.87 = 28 g diethyl ether

prompt.body:
Cisplatin, an anticancer agent used for the treatment of solid tumors, is prepared by the reaction of ammonia with potassium tetrachloroplatinate. Assume that 10.0 g of K2PtCl4 and 10.0 g of NH3 are allowed to react.

K2PtCl4 (aq) + 2 NH3 (aq) → Pt(NH3)2Cl2(s) + 2 KCl(aq)

(a) Which reactant is limiting, and which is in excess?
(b) How many grams of the excess reactant are consumed, and how many grams remain?
(c) How many grams of cisplatin are formed?

STRATEGY
When solving a problem that deals with limiting reactants, the idea is to find how
many moles of all reactants are actually present and compare the mole ratios of those actual amounts to the mole ratios required by the balanced equation. That comparison will identify the reactant there is too much of (the excess reactant) and the reactant there is too little of (the limiting reactant).

values.value:
(a) Finding the molar amounts of reactants always begins by calculating formula
masses and using molar masses as conversion factors:

Molar mass of K2PtCl4= 415.3g/mol

10.0 g/415.3 g/mol = 0.0241mol K2PtCl4

Molar mass of NH3 = 17.0 g/mol

Moles of NH3 = 10.0 g = 0.588 mol NH3

These calculations tell us that we have 0.588 mol of ammonia and 0.0241 mol of K2PtCl4, or times as much ammonia as K2PtCl4. The coefficients in the balanced equation, however, say that only two times as much ammonia as K2PtCl4is needed. Thus, a large excess of NH3 is present, and K2PtCl4 is the limiting reactant.

(b) With the identities of the excess reactant and limiting reactant known, we now have to find how many moles of each undergo reaction and then carry out mole-to-gram conversions to find the mass of each reactant consumed. The entire amount of the limiting reactant (K2PtCl4 ) is used up, but only the amount of the excess reactant (NH3) required by stoichiometry undergoes reaction:

Moles of K2PtCl4 consumed = 0.0241molK2PtCl4

Moles of NH3 consumed = 0.0482 mol NH3

Grams of NH3 consumed = 0.819 g NH3

Grams of NH3 not consumed = (10.0 g - 0.819 g)NH3 = 9.2 g NH3

(c) The balanced equation shows that 1 mol of cisplatin is formed for each mole of
K2PtCl4 consumed. Thus, 0.0241 mol of cisplatin is formed from 0.0241 mol of
K2PtCl4 . To determine the mass of cisplatin produced, we must calculate its molar
mass and then carry out a mole-to-gram conversion:

Molar mass of Pt(NH3)2Cl2 = 300.1g/mol

Grams of Pt(NH3)2Cl2 = 7.23 g Pt(NH3)2Cl2

content.body:
(a) Finding the molar amounts of reactants always begins by calculating formula
masses and using molar masses as conversion factors:

Molar mass of K2PtCl4= 415.3g/mol

10.0 g/415.3 g/mol = 0.0241mol K2PtCl4

Molar mass of NH3 = 17.0 g/mol

Moles of NH3 = 10.0 g = 0.588 mol NH3

These calculations tell us that we have 0.588 mol of ammonia and 0.0241 mol of K2PtCl4, or times as much ammonia as K2PtCl4. The coefficients in the balanced equation, however, say that only two times as much ammonia as K2PtCl4is needed. Thus, a large excess of NH3 is present, and K2PtCl4 is the limiting reactant.

(b) With the identities of the excess reactant and limiting reactant known, we now have to find how many moles of each undergo reaction and then carry out mole-to-gram conversions to find the mass of each reactant consumed. The entire amount of the limiting reactant (K2PtCl4 ) is used up, but only the amount of the excess reactant (NH3) required by stoichiometry undergoes reaction:

Moles of K2PtCl4 consumed = 0.0241molK2PtCl4

Moles of NH3 consumed = 0.0482 mol NH3

Grams of NH3 consumed = 0.819 g NH3

Grams of NH3 not consumed = (10.0 g - 0.819 g)NH3 = 9.2 g NH3

(c) The balanced equation shows that 1 mol of cisplatin is formed for each mole of
K2PtCl4 consumed. Thus, 0.0241 mol of cisplatin is formed from 0.0241 mol of
K2PtCl4 . To determine the mass of cisplatin produced, we must calculate its molar
mass and then carry out a mole-to-gram conversion:

Molar mass of Pt(NH3)2Cl2 = 300.1g/mol

Grams of Pt(NH3)2Cl2 = 7.23 g Pt(NH3)2Cl2
